sdgs.relevance:
We produce country scores for five economic and social rights. These are the rights to education (SDG4), food (SDG2), health (SDG3), housing (SDG6) and work and social assistance (SDG1, SDG8). These scores tell us how well countries are using their available resources to make sure their people can enjoy each of these rights to the maximum extent possible given that country's level of income. Countries with well-functioning governments and effective public sectors perform better, and countries with high levels of corruption or inequality generally perform worse (hence SDG10). Many of the SDG indicators also feed into the Rights Tracker scores. However, unlike the SDGs, our scores are benchmarked according to each country's level of resources. This avoids the income bias problem that is inherent in the SDGs. (i.e. higher income countries generally perform better on most SDG indicators).  This is very important as it has been documented (e.g. by the World Bank) that ESG investment strategies that use the SDGs (and simliar) as indicators of development, skew investment away from lower income countries towards higher income countries. Our award-winning methodology avoids this problem. 

Using a different methodology, we also produce country scores for eight civil and political rights. These relate closely to SDG16 and provide additional metrics not already captured by the SDG16 targets.

userContent.contentManagementPolicy:
All content is vetted and moderated by staff members before being distributed (i.e. published). Nothing is made public without this moderation process. 

We have so far never received illegal material. If such material was received it would be deleted immediately. 

Inappropriate material, according to our guidelines, includes the names of individual people. These are always removed as part of moderation. 

Our policies and processes include the following:
1.	Vetting of contributors (survey respondents), who must be human rights experts nominated by another human rights expert in their country
2.	Directions to contributors about what kind of material to provide
3.	Rigorous training of moderation staff who handle incoming material in the first instance
4.	All material we receive is summarised. No material is reproduced verbatim. 
5.	Material is moderated within a month of receipt, and not published until moderated and edited
6.	Senior leaders at HRMI review and edit all the summaries before any material is distributed
7.	Permanent destruction of all raw material provided within two months of receipt

privacy.privacyCompliance: We comply with the NZ Privacy Act 2020 and the GDPR.
privacy.privacyComplianceURL:
https://humanrightsmeasurement.org/hrmi-privacy-policy/  (Please note that this privacy policy covers not only the Rights Tracker but also other HRMI applications)

It is also worth noting that the data on the Rights Tracker is anonymised data, where anonymised means there is no possible way to link the data with an identifiable indivdual. Our understanding is that the scope of privacy laws (inclduing the NZ Privacy Act 2020 and the EU GDPR) only applies to information about identifiable individuals - thus since the Rights Tracker data are anonymised, they are outside the scope of these privacy laws.
